div.p: Greetings. I received your letter, dear brother, and eagerly await the comic conclusion of your tragedy. May the Lord grant you peace.
Mr. MÃ¼llner himself will write to you, I believe.
He said: "If I had known beforehand that he would give me this wine, I would not have asked him for it." etc. I have nothing else to write at the moment.
You have Beza's letters here; send them back to me.

Greet the most honorable Mr. Legate, to whom I write nothing, so as not to double his troubles; I know he is working, afflicted, and distressed. He has dealings with such people with whom it is not easy to transact conveniently.
Many letters have now been written by me to Frankfurt and are being written; therefore, I am brief.

Froschauer left yesterday well-laden with my letters; tomorrow other merchants of ours will follow. I am still writing more even to Heidelberg; therefore, I will include yours with mine and hand them over to those departing tomorrow morning at dusk.
To the most excellent Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Church of Chur, my esteemed and beloved lord and brother. Chur.
